affiliation.orgName: Event-Triggered Pinning Control for Consensus of Multiagent Systems With Quantized Information
National Laboratory of Industrial Control Technology
School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering

analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

biblStruct.note: received August 22, 2017; revised October 29, 2017; accepted November 10, 2017.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, the problem of distributed eventtriggered pinning control for practical consensus of multiagent systems (MASs) with quantized communication based on a directed graph is investigated. The pinning control for practical consensus of MASs with uniform quantizer is first discussed. Then, in order to decrease communication load of interagent, the event-triggered quantized communication protocol is designed. The nonsmooth analysis and Gronwall's inequality approach is used to guarantee the existence of a solution to the resulting closed-loop system. It is shown that practical consensus is reachable through the event-triggered control and converges to a consensus set. Moreover, "Zeno phenomenon" can be excluded. Finally, an example is given to validate the feasibility and efficiency of the proposed new design method.
their neighbors. Some typical results of consensus have been presented in [1]- [7].

Pinning control [8]- [10] is a feedback control strategy for synchronization and consensus of MASs. Specifically, a virtual leader (the pinner) is added to the interaction topology network and defines its desired trajectory. The pinner directly controls a small part of all pinned agents, then the rest agents are connected via their neighboring agents. For example, the tracking control problem, a team of agents is able to coordinate through exchanging information while tracking the trajectory of the leader [11]- [13]. Recently, a great number of works related to the pinning control are to investigate the design of the pinning control protocol [14]- [16], or find the sufficient condition of the consensus problem, or choose the optimal agent to control and then provide a criterion. Although interagent in MASs communicates over topology network, the communication network has its disadvantages, such as limited bandwidth. Hence, information transfer needs to be quantized or coded before the transmission. Some existing results of quantized consensus can be founded in [17]- [21] and reference therein.

Consider the underlying communication imperfections and constraints [22], such as limited energy resource and bandwidth in a real environment. Quantized control approach, as an effective control strategy, can deal with those limitations, where uniform quantizer has been popular with researchers. For example, Frasca et al. [23] and Nedic et al. [24] adopted uniform quantizers to address consensus of single integrator discrete-time MASs and practical consensus problem were achieved owing to the restriction of uniform quantization. However, it fails to find a traditional root for right-side of discontinuous right-hand sides of differential equations when investigating continuous-time MASs with quantized communication. Frasca [25] discussed the convergence of Krasovskii solution for the continuous-time quantized consensus with time-varying directed topology. It is shown that if there exists one agent which can reach any of agents in the interaction graph, Krasovskill solutions reach consensus after a finite time.

In order to decrease the communication load of interagent, the event-triggered control (ETC) approach, as an effective control strategy, can save network energy consumption. The ETC was first proposed by Tabuada [26], which mainly studied the stabilization problem, where the event-trigger function is executed when an established error outnumbers the threshold. ETC has then been extensively investigated by many researchers. Dimarogonas et al. [27] first proposed an ETC scheme to deal with a single-integrator consensus problem 2168-2216 c 2017 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

and then spread to self-triggered control in MASs. In [28], it developed a novel combination measurement method to solve consensus of MASs via event-triggered controller. This approach can greatly decrease the communication load of interagent. In [29], an event-triggered sampling strategy for the leader-following consensus with second-order dynamics is studied, where an event-trigger function is designed based on the states of each agent and neighbors' states. More results on ETC were presented in [30]- [33].

In the wide applications of MAS in different fields, it is necessary for researchers to consider how to deal with communication constraints and how to save network resources. By combining the quantized control and the ETC, the above problem can be solved with the following reasons. First, there exist limited networked storage and interaction bandwidth in network control systems or MASs, and the quantized control approach can solve the drawback. Second, network resources are limited in communication network, and in order to obtain the better cooperative performance by reducing the communication load of interagent, the ETC shows its advantage to save network resources. However, there are a few literatures to deal with the consensus of MASs by combining quantized control and ETC [18], [34]. Yu et al. [18] considered an event-triggered consensus of linear MASs with quantized measurements in finite time, however, the communication graph is an undirected graph. Consensus of linear discrete-time MASs with delayed quantized communication by ETC approach is investigated in [34].

However, we can observe that the above literatures focused on the linear systems and the undirected graph. If the dynamics of MASs are nonlinear with a directed graph, it becomes more challenging. The nonlinear MASs are investigated in [35]- [37] and reference therein. In [36], an adaptive distributed ETC law was given to study the event-based leader-follower consensus problem for a directed network of Euler-Lagrange agents. Mu et al. [37] employed the eventtriggered approach to investigate the consensus problem of MASs with Euler-Lagrange dynamics based on two uniform sampling and arbitrary nonuniform sampling schemes. Sufficient conditions of achieving consensus were presented. However, the quantized control is rarely considered, and this motivates us to investigate the leader-following consensus of MASs by combining event-triggered pinning control, and quantized communication.

In this paper, the consensus of nonlinear MASs with quantized information via event-triggered pinning control mechanism is studied. The integration of the quantized control and the event-triggered pinning control has the advantages listed as follows.

First, many results of the quantized consensus of linear multiagent have been reported [18], [35]. However, these works are based on a hypothesis that the communication graph between agents is undirected. However, bilateral communication between agents is rare in some real cases, which urges us to study quantized consensus problem of MASs in directed interaction graph on the basis of an assumption. The assumption is that a spanning tree exists in directed interaction topology and the leader is the root of the graph.

Second, most systems are nonlinear or with nonlinearities in practical settings. A new control law on the basis of quantized state is constructed to cope with the consensus problem of nonlinear MASs, where the quantized state information of agents can be transferred by their neighbors to achieve coordinations. The introduction of quantized control can effectively deal with the limited bandwidth of the network.

Third, the limited network resource is also a crucial factor for communication of agents, which leads to the ETC strategy being taken into account. Inspired by [12] the ETC and the quantized control are introduced and an event-triggered function based on the local quantized state information is designed to obtain practical consensus of nonlinear MASs. Practical consensus means that the consensus error converges to a bounded range rather than converges to zero. It is worth noting that by employing the nonsmooth analysis and Gronwall's inequality technique, the practical consensus result is reachable and converges to a consensus set. As a result, "Zeno behavior" is also excluded.

This paper is organized as follows. Some definitions including graph theory, uniform quantizer, nonsmooth analysis (differential inclusion and Krasovskii solution), problem formulation, and the objective of control are given in Section II. Section III discusses the quantized consensus of nonlinear MASs and gives the main results. An examples is presented to illustrate the feasibility and efficiency of our method in Section IV. Finally, some conclusions are drawn in Section V.

Notations: I N indicates the indentity matrix with dimension N. denotes the set of real numbers. n indicates real column vectors with dimension n. n×n denotes real matrices. For a given matrix , λ( ) represents the characteristic root of matrix , T is the transpose of a matrix . • denotes 2-norm. ⊗ denotes the Kronecker product of matrices and .

div.head: A. Graph Theory
div.p: In MASs, each agent communicates with its neighbors via an interaction topology network. More detailed concepts can be founded in [38]. Define G = (V, E, A) as a weighted directed graph, where V = {ν 1 , ν 2 , . . . ν N } represents the set of vertexes, E ⊆ V × V represents an edge set of ordered pairs of vertexes and A = [a ij ] ∈ N×N represents an adjacency matrix. If vertex j can receive information from vertex i and i = j, we can call there exists a directed edge (i, j) existing the edge set of a directed graph. The set of neighbors of ν i can be described as
div.formula: N i = {j ∈ V | (i, j) ∈ E}. A directed path from ν i to ν j is a sequence of ordered edges in E, denoted by (ν i , ν m ), (ν m+1 , ν m+2 ), . . . (ν j-1 , ν j ) with differ- ent vertexes.
div.p: G is a strongly connected graph if between every pair of different vertexes ν i , ν j in G, there is a directed path that begins at ν i and ends at ν j . A directed tree means that every vertex in G has a parent vertex, except the root vertex. If ν i is regarded as a root in the directed graph, and there exists directed paths for ν i to all other vertexes, we can call there exists a directed spanning tree in the directed graph G.
div.formula: For A = [a ij ] ∈ N×N , if (ν i , ν j ) ∈ E, we have a ij = 1 and a ij = 0, otherwise. Degree matrix D in the directed graph G is defined as D = diag(g 1 , g 2 , . . . , g N ), where g(i) = N j=1,j =i a ij . Laplacian matrix L of graph G is defined as L = [l ij ] and satisfies L = D -A, where l ij = N j=1,j =i a ij , i = j and l ij = -a ij , i = j.
div.p: A leader, label ν 0 , is considered in the directed graph, then we have a graph Ḡ that contains G and the leader label ν 0 . Let N pin = {i 10 , . . . i 1l } ⊆ V be a pin set in the directed graph Ḡ. Define P = diag{p 10 , . . . , p N0 } > 0 as the inner coupling matrix. If i ∈ N pin , p i0 > 0, and p i0 < 0 otherwise.

div.head: B. Uniform Quantizer
div.p: A uniform quantizer q u : → is defined as follows:
div.formula: q u (x) = θ x θ + 1 2(1)
div.p: where θ > 0 represents the gain of uniform quantizer. Define u as quantization error and u satisfies the equation: q u (x)x = u , where the quantization error u ∈ (-[θ/2], [θ/2]) responses to the accuracy of the quantizer directly and satisfies q u (x)x ≤ (θ/2) for all x ∈ . According to the definition of a uniform quantizer, it is also suitable for vector case. For example, for any vector x = [x 1 , . . . , x N ] T , define the vector uniform quantization q v (•) : n → n to be q v (x x x) ≡ [q v (x 1 ), . . . , q v (x n )] T . Then, we can obtain the following result:
div.formula: q v (x x x) -x x x ≤ n(θ/2).

div.head: C. Nonsmooth Analysis
div.p: For a differential equation [39]

where f (x(t), t) : × n → n is a measurable and discontinuous function. Note that the existence of a continuously differential equation solution is not guaranteed. Hence, the Krasovskii solution is introduced to discuss the solution of the differential equation. The reason why we adopt the notion of Krasovskii solutions is that the set of Krasovskii solution includes Filippov and Caratheodory solutions and the conclusions about Krasovskii solutions also holds for Filippov and Caratheodory solutions. A vector function x(t) is called the Krasovskii solution of (2) on [t 0 , t 1 ) if x(t) is absolutely continuous on [t 0 , t 1 ), and satisfies
where co denotes the convex closure and B(x, δ) is the Euclidean ball centered in x with the radius δ. If f (•) is measurable and locally bounded, then x is the Krasovskill solution of (2).

div.head: D. Problem Formulation
div.p: Consider a nonlinear MASs consisting of N identical agents and the leader is labeled with subscript 0. The pinning control model of the ith agent (i = 1, . . . N) can be expressed as follows:
div.formula: ẋi (t) = f (x i (t), t) + u i (t) (4)
div.p: where x i (t) ∈ n and u i (t) ∈ p are the state and control input of the ith agent. f (x i (t), t) is a continuously vector value function denoting dynamics of agents. The pinner, labeled as 0, has the dynamic as

where s(t) is the state of the leader and s(t) = (s 1 (t), . . . , s n (t)) T ∈ n . Note that (1) and (2) have nonlinear functions. Assume that f (x i (t), t) satisfies the Lipschitz condition with a Lipschitz constant α > 0 as

The control objective of this paper is to deal with practical consensus problem of nonlinear MASs via designing quantized consensus protocol and an event-triggered quantized control protocol, respectively. Moreover, the Zeno behavior needs to be excluded in ETC case.

Definition 1: For any initial x i (0), i = 1, 2, . . . N and arbitrary consensus set χ > 0, the practical quantized consensus of nonlinear MASs is obtained, if the states of all agents satisfy lim t→∞ x i (t)s(t) ≤ χ (7) where χ denotes the error bounds. We can observe from Definition 1 that there exists an error between states of the leader and states of the followers. It is necessary to estimate the error bounds (consensus set χ ). The Gronwall's inequality is an effective tool to solve the problem.
Lemma 1 (Gronwall's Inequality) [40]:
div.formula: Let = [t 0 , t) denotes an real interval. if u(t) satisfies u u u(t) ≤ (t) + ζ ζ ζ (t) t t 0 (ω)u u u(ω)dω, t ∈(8)

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, we first discuss the quantized control for a practical consensus of nonlinear MASs; then, by introducing the ETC, practical consensus of nonlinear MASs based on the above case is investigated.

div.head: A. Quantized Control
div.p: We consider the following the quantized control protocol:
div.formula: u i (t) = Z j∈N i a ij q u x j (t) -q u (x i (t)) + p i0 Z(q u (s(t)) -q u (x i (t))) (10
div.p: where Z is an inner coupling matrix and λ(Z) > 0. q u (x i ) denotes quantized state of the ith agent. If i ∈ N pin , p i0 > 0, and p i0 = 0 otherwise. Define i (t) = x i (t)s(t) as the state consensus error, then we can obtain (11) where i (t) = q u (x i (t))x i (t). Note that there exist discontinuous functions f (x i (t), t) and f (s(t), t) on the right hand of (11). Krasovskii solutions of (11) are expressed by

div.head: B. Event-Triggered Quantized Control
div.p: In order to exclude the unnecessary continuous interaction while saving limited network resources in the communication network of MASs, we introduce ETC based on the control law (10) to address the practical consensus problem. The structure of an event-triggered MASs with quantizer is shown in Fig. 1. Assume that t i k is the event-triggering time sequence of the ith agent denoting t i 0 , t i 1 , . . . , t i ∞ . Inspired by [11], the eventtriggered quantized control protocol is developed as follows:
div.formula: u i (t) = Z j∈N i a ij q u x j t i k -q u x i t i k + p i0 Z q u s t i k -q u x i t i k . (17
div.p: Remark 1: In the control protocol (17), we prefer to choose x j (t i k ) rather than x j (t
div.formula: j k ), k (t) m∈Z + :t>t j m = argmin(t -t j m
div.p: ), as in [27]. The reason is that the controller u i (t) is updated immediately once agent i samples its quantized state value in triggering time instants or receives the sample quantized state value from one of its neighbors. However, the controller does not need updating even though one of its neighbors completes sampling in (17).
The state measurement errors like in [12] are defined as
div.formula: e i (t) = q u x i t i k -x i (t) -i t i k (18

div.p: Considering the consensus set χ > 0, so we have κ > α + 6γ 2 π N (1/[1 -2γ 2 N]) and γ < √ (1/2N). Next, we will prove that Zeno behavior is not presented. We all know that Zeno behavior exists in practical environment. Zeno behavior indicates that an infinite number of event-triggering processes occur in finite time. Usually, this phenomenon is required to be eliminated as it may make the system unstable. Hence, we will prove that Zeno behavior does not exist in the proposed protocol, namely, there exists a positive lower bound τ . The proof of Zeno behavior is inspired by the proof in [41].
Based on (18), ones have

div.p: Assume that τ = t i k+1t i k , we have

We use the contradiction method to verify the existence of a positive lower bound τ > 0. First, we assume that τ = 0, then the right side of (37) is not equal to i χ . Similarly, if τ < 0, two sides are not equivalent, hence, there exists a positive lower bound τ > 0 and Zeno behavior can be excluded. Remark 2. The linear dynamics of agents are usually modeled as a single-integrator and a double-integrator in MASs. Compared to the linear systems, the nonlinear dynamics of agents in MASs are more complex and challenging. In addition, the derived results in this paper contain some common results if f (x i (t), t) = 0.

div.head: IV. VERIFICATION EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, an examples is displayed to testify the availability of our results.

Consider the communication topology between agents of a nonlinear MAS has five followers and the leader (the pinner), labeled as 0, is shown in Fig. 2. Then the Laplacian matrix L of graph G is given as and the matrix P 0 = diag(0.3, 0.35, 0, 0, 0) T . It is easy to calculate that eigenvalues of the matrix L are 0.8596 ± 0.1926i, 0.3904 ± 0.1387i, 0, respectively. Let Z = diag(1.5, 1, 1). Assume that the nonlinear dynamics of every agent are described by

The original values for five followers and the pinner are selected randomly in [0, 2.5]. According to the (6), the Lipchitz constant α can be calculated as α = 2.7545. γ = 0.08. Based on the above algorithm, we can observe that the three states (x i1 , x i2 , x i3 ) of five followers synchronize with states of the Pinner s as shown in Fig. 3 with uniform quantizer (θ = 0.1). Fig. 4 presents the bounds of the consensus errors with different quantization levels (the first set parameter: θ = 1.2 and the second set parameter: θ = 0.8).
Fig. 5 presents that consensus error = 5 i=1 (x is) 2 tends to 0 asymptotically.

When the ETC is introduced, Fig. 6 denotes event-triggering time instants of five followers. The first states of five followers' control inputs are presented in Fig. 7, and the other states are similar. Fig. 8 illustrates that followers synchronize the pinner with ETC mechanism. For the ETC case, the bounds of the consensus errors with different quantization levels (the first set parameter: θ = 1.2 and the second set parameter: θ = 0.8) are given in Figs. 9 and 10. The consensus error tends to 0 with the ETC as shown in Fig. 11. By comparing Figs. 5 and 11, we can clearly observe that the two cases have the same convergence speed, and the calculation of the consensus error with the ETC in Fig. 11 is less than calculation of the consensus error in Fig. 5. It implies that the ETC method shows better performance under the limited network resources, since this approach has less communication between agents, and can also save the network resources.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: This paper adopts the event-triggered pinning control to address practical consensus of MASs with state quantization in directed graph, where there exists a spanning tree in communication topology. First, consensus problem of nonlinear MASs via quantized control is discussed due to existence of network constraints. Then for the sake of reducing the frequent information exchange between agents, the ETC is taken into account on the basis of the former case to investigate practical consensus problem. It is shown that the practical consensus is solvable by nonsmooth analysis and Gronwall's inequality techniques for two cases. Moreover, Zeno behavior is not displayed in ETC case. We provide an example to demonstrate the effectiveness of the theoretic results obtained.
